item.description: WASHINGTON, September 3. From HEADQUARTERS ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, SATURDAY, Aug. 29, 1863. The dull monotony of this Summer camp life has been agreeably broken within the past few days by the occurrence of one or two of those pleasant occasions which are not only agreeable in themselves, but serve to bind anew and with still stronger ties the affections of the soldiers to their leaders. The first occurred on Wednesday at Warrenton, when an elegant horse, sword, and set of equipments were presented to Gen. SEDGWICK, by the officers of his old command, the Second division of the Second Army Corps.

WASHINGTON, September 2. From CINCINATTI, Saturday, Aug. 29. Late information from Vicksburgh confirms the death of Gen. PEMBERTON. He was shot by Texan soldiers. A Union meeting was recently held at Pelham, Greenbriar county, Tenn. Resolutions were passed expressive of a desire to return to the Union, repudiating the act of secession passed in 1861. Gen. GRANT was tendered the hospitalities of Memphis on Wednesday last. There was 600 Illinois troops on the steamer Courier when she collided with the Des Arc. Fifty thousand rounds of ammunition and all the guns and knapsacks and baggage of the soldiers were lost.

WASHINGTON, September 1. To-day there was a fierce artillery fight at Port Royal, Virginia. Knoxville, Tennessee, has been captured by Gen. Foster of Burnside's army. Fort Smith, Arkansas, is now occupied by our forces. VICKSBURGH, Miss., Thursday, Aug. 20, 1863. Gen. GRANT and Gen. THOMAS left yesterday for Memphis, and it is the intention of the former to visit Columbus also. and perhaps Cairo. It would not be at all surprising if the telegraph should get hold of this unimportant fact, and find therein confirmation of the canard that he had been called to the command of the Army of the Potomac.

WASHINGTON, August 31. Fort Moultrie, Charleston harbor, was attacked to-day. Rear-Admiral PORTER forwards the report of Lieut. BACHE, relative to the White River expedition. He first stopped at Des Arc, on the White River, and burnt Confederate stores, destroyed the telegraph wires, etc., and then sent the Cricket after the steamers Tom Gregg and Kaskaskia, which he had reason to believe were hid up the river, while he and the Marmora proceeded to Augusta, thirty miles further. There he obtained valuable information of the enemy, namely: that the grand Southern army was concentrating at Brownsville, to make their line of defence on the Bayou Meto.

WASHINGTON, August 30. The Army of the Cumberland has crossed the Tennessee River. A dispatch received from Fortress Monroe yesterday, announced the reception of news there that Forts Sumter and Wagner were occupied by our forces on Monday last, the 24th. To show that the news is unreliable, it is only necessary to refer to the fact that the Arago, whose advices we published yesterday, did not leave Charleston bar until the 25th -- the day after its alleged occupation -- at which time the rebels still had possession. We also have this morning an official dispatch from Gen. GILLMORE, dated the 24th, announcing the practical demolition of Sumter.

WASHINGTON, August 29. From CHARLESTON, Tuesday, Aug. 18. All day yesterday the bombardment was more furious than on any day. The Ironsides, six monitors and six gunboats, with all the enemy's land batteries, opened on battery Wagner at daybreak, throwing twenty shells per minute at our works. This continued until 11 o'clock, when the fleet and land batteries turned their attention to Fort Sumter. The Ironsides and six monitors approached within three-quarters of a mile of Fort Sumter, and battered vigorously against the south face of the fort. Sumter replied vigorously from her barbette guns. The contest lasted about three hours.

WASHINGTON, August 28. The rebels have driven across Bayou Metairie Bridge, Arkansas, with considerable loss. MORRIS ISLAND, S.C., Friday, Aug. 21, 1863. The orders issued by Gen. GILLMORE Sunday night, for the artillery commanders to open their batteries on the rebel works at daybreak Monday morning, did not, in consequence of the advanced state of our siege operations, create any undue surprise. News of attack was circulated with remarkable rapidity through the camp, and upon the countenances of the soldiers could be traced evidences of satisfaction, if not actual delight, at the prospect of being relieved of the monotonous life.

WASHINGTON, August 27. From Richmond. Rebel John B. Floyd died to-day. The Sentinel announces that no paper would be issued from its establishment on the following day, in consequence of JEFF. DAVIS' Fast occurring on Friday. Brig.-Gen. ROGER A. PRYOR, commonly known as Bowie-knife PRYOR, has tendered his resignation to the rebel War Department, and it has been accepted. An accident occurred recently near Fort Deposit, on the Alabama and Florida road. A brake got under one of the cars, throwing it off, along with seven other cars, by which three soldiers of a South Carolina regiment were killed and thirty wounded.

WASHINGTON, August 26. An expedition has left Williamsburgh, Virginia, for Bottom's Bridge, Virginia. There has been an attack on the rebel rifle pits near Fort Wagner. JACKSON, MISS., Tuesday, August 18. The Federal cavalry from Yazoo City have reached Durot Station, on the Mississippi Railroad, where they captured a train and cut the telegraph wires. Serious destruction on the railroad northward is apprehended. The Yankees are carrying two engines and trains northward from Vaden. and a heavy raid is coming southward from the Charleston Railroad.

WASHINGTON, August 25. DESERTIONS FROM LEE'S ARMY. LEE's army is daily decreasing in strength -- the number of desertions from it outnumbering the conscripts daily joining it. At no previous period of the war has there been so great a disposition manifested to desert from it. Deserters now number now four or five times as many as ever before, and by far the greater portion of them are natives. They unite in declaring that nine-tenths of those who are now deserting LEE make for their respective homes, instead of coming this way. They also say that the feeling that the rebel cause is lost is universal in the rebel army of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, August 24. Charleston, South Carolina, was again shelled by Gen. Gillmore to-day. SARATOGA, New York, Friday, Aug. 14, 1863. Correspondence of the New-York Times. There has been a very large assemblage of Christian patriots here to-day, at a Convention of the Christian Commission, which crowded the Baptist Church in this place morning and evening. President HOPKINS, of Williams College presided. After the reading of the Scriptures and prayer, Rev. GEO. J. MINGINS, a delegate of the Commission, made a most earnest and eloquent address. Some of the incidents which he related drew tears from unaccustomed eyes.

WASHINGTON, August 23. Fort Fisher, near Wilmington, North Carolina, has been bombarded by the frigate Minnesota. Gen. SIBLEY telegraphs, under date of the 7th inst., that he has had three engagements with 2,200 Sioux warriors, in all of which the Indians were routed, and finally driven across the Missouri River, with the loss of all their subsistence, etc., and at least one hundred and fifty killed and wounded. The loss among the white troops was but seven killed and wounded. Gen. POPE considers Indian hostilities east of the Missouri as at an end, LITTLE CROW, the principal Chief, having been killed, and his son captured.

WASHINGTON, August 22. C.S. Gen. Beauregard has protested against the shelling of the City of Charleston. ST. LOUIS, Saturday, Aug. 15. Col. CATHERWOOD, commanding Sixth Artillery Missouri State Militia, telegraphed Headquarters, as follows: PINSVILLE, MCDONALD CO., Mo., Saturday, Aug. 15. Col. COFFEE attacked me to-day, He is completely routed, with over 30 killed and wounded. We have a large number of prisoners, all his ammunition wagons, commissary stores, arms, horses, etc. We scattered all his command except 200 with himself. A force is following him closely. My horses are so worn down they cannot move farther until rested.

WASHINGTON, August 21. Lawrence, Kansas, has been pillaged and burned by the guerrillas. Gen. Gillmore has demanded the surrender of Morris island and Fort Sumter, and threatened to shell Charleston in case of non-compliance with his demand. Our batteries opened on Charleston, South Carolina, during the night. The advance of the Army of the Cumberland has appeared before Chattanooga, Tennessee, and opened fire on the city.

WASHINGTON, August 20. Fort Sumter continues to be bombarded to-day. Gen. Rosecrans' forces have reached the Tennessee River. QUEBEC, Friday, Aug. 14. Parliament assembled yesterday and elected Hon. LEWIS WALBRIDGR Speaker by eight majority. To-day the Governor-General delivered the opening speech. He directed special attention to the Militia law, which, he said, required extensive amendment in order to make it effective. The establishment of telegraphic and postal communication between Lake Superior and the Pacific coast was recommended as a matter for the consideration of the Parliament.

WASHINGTON, August 19. The bombardment of Fort Sumter is continuing to-day. The draft in New York city has recommenced. SAN FRANCISCO, Thursday, Aug. 13. As was anticipated yesterday, the reports of secession risings in Santa Clara and Saline Counties were untrue. Gen. WRIGHT has just received orders and funds from Washington, to construct new harbor defenses, for San Francisco. Batteries mounted by guns of large calibre are to be erected at Rincon Point, Rincon Hill, Buena Vista Island, and probably on Telegraph Hill.

WASHINGTON, August 18. Fort Sumter has continued to be bombarded to-day. SAN FRANCISCO, Tuesday, Aug. 11. The State is full of rumors of a contemplated rising of the Secessionists, consequently there is an uneasy feeling in the public mind. On the 6th an affray occurred at Visalia, a small town in Tillare County, between the Secessionists and the soldiers stationed there. One of the latter was killed. Several of the former were wounded. Thirty-six shots were exchanged. Gen. WRIGHT, the military commander at San Francisco, telegraphed that all the spare arms among the soldiers at Visalia, be distributed among the loyal citizens.

WASHINGTON, August 17. There has been great destruction of rebel property at Grenada by our troops from Tennessee. A grand attack on Fort Sumter has commenced by both the iron-clad fleet and land batteries. The steamer City of Madison exploded to-day on the Mississippi River. A reconnaissance in force by the rebel army has reportedly begun in Virginia. The steamer Nita has been captured running out of Mobile, Alabama. Gen. Dix made an address to the citizens of New York relative to the draft.

WASHINGTON, August 16. The steamer Alice Vivian has been captured running out of Mobile. Gen. Rosecrans has commenced his advance across the Cumberland mountains. Large numbers of contrabands continue to arrive within our lines, embracing men, women and children of all ages, and even colors, some having but very little African blood coursing their veins. Those that arrived yesterday state that there is no force of rebels this side of Little Washington. They also report that thousands of slaves are huddled together, and are now preparing to come within our lines. All of the young, athletic negroes express a great desire to enter the army as soldiers.

WASHINGTON, August 15. The authorities of the City of New York have appropriated SX 3,000,000 to pay for substitutes. The following telegram released to-day. HEADQUARTERS ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, WARRENTON, July 31, 1863. QN OFFICIAL, QN CHARLES E. PEASE, A.A.G. HEADQUARTERS CAVALRY CORPS, July 31, 1863. The Major-General Commanding directs that under this order every man shall take the oath of allegiance, or be arrested and sent in. You will have this order published to the officers under your command. By command of (Signed) Maj.-Gen. PLEASANTON. A.J. COHEN, A.A.G.

WASHINGTON, August 14. Commodore Morris died to-day. The following telegram released to-day. UNITED STATES MILITARY TELEGRAPH, BY TELEGRAPH FROM WASHINGTON, July 31, 1863 -- 4 P.M. To Maj.-Gen. Meade: Cant. MEANS reports that about (500) five hundred of the enemy's cavalry have appeared at Point of Rocks. The present time should be availed of to drive out every guerrilla and disloyal man between the Potomac, Rappahannock and Blue Ridge. (Signed,) H.W. HALLECK, General-in-Chief.

WASHINGTON, August 13. An expedition has left Lagrange, Tennessee, for Central Mississippi. NEW YORK, August 12. The Cunard mail steamer China, Capt. ANDERSON, which left Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 1st, and Queenstown on the 2d of August, arrived here last evening. A telegraphic summary of her news has already been published, as received from Cape Race. Dispatches from Rio Janeiro, vid Lisbon, report that the American ships Talisman, bound from New-York for Shanghai, and the Comod, bound from Montevideo for New-York, had been captured by the Alabama. Their crews were landed at Rio. No further particulars are given.

WASHINGTON, August 12. Fort Sumter, Charleston harbor, has been battered by our shot. The rebels opened on our works near Charleston with grape and canister. BUFFALO, Monday, Aug. 10. The draft in this city was concluded to-day. It passed off quietly, though every necessary precaution was taken. Six employees of the telegraph office were drafted. NEW YORK, Aug. 12. The officers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad announced that that great thoroughfare is opened anew for freight and travel, through its entire length, from Baltimore to Wheeling. Over 18,000 ties, hundreds of tons of rail, and 30 miles of telegraph wire were taken away or destroyed by rebels.

WASHINGTON, August 11. A thousand conscripts a day are now arriving at the Army of the Potomac, and attaching themselves to the old regiments. They go forward in excellent spirits. Substitutes are offering themselves at very cheap rates, both in Philadelphia and Washington, as well as at other points where drafting is going on. Prices range from one hundred to two hundred dollars, and cases are reported where persons voluntarily and freely offer themselves as substitutes for their drafted friends. A thousand conscripts a day, and the volume constantly increasing! The ranks of the army will soon be filled up at this rate. The shadowy regiments will soon be full-bodied.

WASHINGTON, August 10. From MORTON, Mississippi, July 25, 1863. GRANT has fallen back toward Vicksburgh. The evacuation is likely permanent, and West Mississippi will be left to the mercy of raiders. The gathering of a heavy naval force at Pensacola would indicate an early attack on Mobile, but the difficulties in the way of GRANT's participation in it are very great. He will hardly attempt it by land from the river. Want of water, hot weather and sickness will deter him. It is more probable that, content with his exploits in the South for the present, he will merely hold the strategic points he has gained, and operate the balk of his army somewhere North.

WASHINGTON, August 9. BALTIMORE. Aug. 8 -- Arr. schr. Yorktown. Wyland New-York. Cld. brigs Harkaway, Wilson, Montevideo, Elisha Doane. Jones. Cardenas. Sarah Atlec, (Br..) Pictou, N.S.. schrs. White Cloud. Leavitt New-York via Wicomico River, Md.. June, Small, do. Via do. CHICAGO, Wednesday, Aug. 5, 1863. The National Teacher's Convention convened in this city. The school-masters are indeed abroad, and the school-mistresses with them, in large and unexpected numbers. It would seem that New-England has heard that she was to be left out in the cold by a certain class of Western politicians, when they reconstruct the Union.

WASHINGTON, August 8. On the Day of National Thanksgiving, August 6, thousands of clergymen held forth from their pulpits. In our Armies, stationed on the Potomac, on the Tennessee, on the Upper and Lower Mississippi, and on the headwaters of the Arkansas -- in our Navy, stationed all along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, and on all the rivers of the South -- our soldiers and our sailors kept holiday, and acknowledged that not alone their own valor and endurance, but a higher Power had led them on to victory. In the City of San Francisco, as we learn by telegraph, there were national salutes and ringing of bells morning, noon and night.

WASHINGTON, August 7. President Lincoln has sent a reply to New York Gov. Seymour's letter of remonstrance against the draft, in which the president asserted that the draft should proceed. HAVANA, Saturday, Aug. 1, 1863. The latest news from Mexico comes to us from St. Jago de Cuba, whither it was carried by the French mail steamer Florida. The most important subject is the confirmation of the proclamation of the Empire, and of Prince MAXIMILIAN as Emperor.

WASHINGTON, August 6. The ship Francis B. Cutting has been captured and bonded by the Florida. To-day is National Thanksgiving Day. The draft in four out of seven Wards in this city has been completed. It embraces 2,600 whites and 818 colored men. Amongst the drafted are three clergymen, as many members of the City Councils, and several telegraph operators. also, reporters, printers, lawyers and representatives of all classes of business. A party of drafted men attempted yesterday to escape from the city, but were apprehended as deserters. Judge-Advocate HOLT has given the opinion that Paymasters Clerks are not found in the list of exempted classes.

WASHINGTON, August 5. Adj.-Gen. THOMAS leaves to-morrow for the West, to organize more negro regiments. He will proceed directly to Memphis, and from that point to New-Orleans, organizing regiments all along the River. He will be gone three or four months, and has the same full powers as before. NEWBERN, N.C, Saturday, July 25, 1863. A very successful cavalry raid was made a few days since by a detachment comprising twelve companies of the Third New-York cavalry, three companies of Mix's new cavalry, Companies A, B and C of the Twelfth New-York cavalry, with one company North Carolina Union Volunteers, Brig.-Gen. POTTER in command.

WASHINGTON, August 4. An engagement occurred to-day near Brandy Station, Virginia. The steamer Ruth, with SX 2,500,000 in government funds, burned to-day on the Mississippi River. A reconnaissance of Fort Darling on the James River is completed. MEMPHIS, August 1. Gen. GRANT has perfected a complete system of mounted patrols between Vicksburgh and New-Orleans, which, with the gunboats, affords ample protection to vessels.

WASHINGTON, August 3. New York Gov. Seymour has indicted a letter to the President, remonstrating against the enforcement of the draft in New York because of unfair enrollment etc. The telegraph brings from Memphis the statement QN removal of the slaves from Mississippi into Alabama and Georgia has been carried to such an extent that the Governors of those States have issued proclamations forbidding their further introduction, and Gen. JOHNSTON's pickets have turned a large number back. QN Most of these slaves have learned by this time that the war which is raging around them, and driving them from one place to another, has something to do with their freedom.

WASHINGTON, August 2. From PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, July 30. Three wards underwent the process of the draft to-day, the First, the Sixth and the Eleventh. As usual, everything passed off quietly. Among those who were so QN fortunate QN as to be honored with the draft to-day were three more telegraphers, making fifteen in all from the American Company, including JAMES MERRIHEW, Assistant Manager. JAMES J. REVILLE, of the Continental office, and WILLIAM CARLEY, clerk. It is proposed by these QN lucky QN telegraphers to apply for a separate organization, as a company for telegraphic duty.

WASHINGTON, August 1. A battle occurred to-day between the cavalry of the two armies near Culpepper, Virginia. Jefferson Davis has appealed to the deserters from the rebel army to return, offering them pardon and amnesty. NEW HAVEN, August 1. There are about 200 drafted men and substitutes at Grapevine Point, the conscript camp near New-Haven. Saturday night, fifteen substitutes who had received their pay, attempted to run the guard and escape, but were fired upon. Most of them were driven back to the camp, but four or five escaped. One fellow, calling himself JOHN MCCARTEN, of Toronto, was hit and his arm shattered so that amputation was necessary.

WASHINGTON, July 31. There has been heavy bombarding of our works on Morris Island, Charleston harbor, from Fort Wagner. To-day there was a successful attack on the rebels at Lancaster, Kentucky. A reconnaissance mission has reportedly been made to Sperryville, Virginia. PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, July 29. The draft in the Fifth Ward of this city was completed to-day. Among those who have been so QN lucky QN as to he drawn are Mr. MORRIS HARDING, of the Philadelphia Inquirer, and five telegraph operators attached to the American and National lines. BUFFALO, Wednesday, July 29. The draft at Lockport was completed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30. President Lincoln has issued a proclamation to-day in regard to rebel treatment of colored troops. The Cummings Point rebel battery at Charleston harbor has been bombarded. Rebels were defeated to-day at Winchester, Kentucky. A special correspondent telegraphs from the Army of the Potomac, under date of yesterday, that the army now occupies practically the same line that it did two months ago, and that the recent active movements will necessarily be followed by a period of comparative inaction. During the next month the cavalry is expected to do most of the fighting.

WASHINGTON, July 29. Rebels have been repulsed to-day at Paris, Kentucky. PHILADELPHIA, July 28. Jacob Forney, an engineer on the Pennsylvania Central Railroad, was killed on July 6 while in the discharge of his duties. When the train under his charge was near Coatesville, Chester County, deceased was in the act of looking back at his train from the window, when his head struck a telegraph pole, with such force as to crush it in a shocking manner.

WASHINGTON, July 28. Confederate States Senator and orator, William L. Yancey of Alabama, has died to-day. The rebels have been defeated at Lexington, Tennessee. FORTRESS MONROE, Tuesday, July 28. Flag-of-truce steamer New-York arrived from City Point last evening, in charge of Capt. MULFORD. She brings no prisoners. She brings Richmond papers to the 27th. The propeller United States arrived here this afternoon with 154 rebel prisoners, which were sent to Fort Norfolk. The steamer New-York left here at 2 o'clock P.M., for Annapolis.

WASHINGTON, July 27. Dispatches indicate that Gen. LEE's army is out of the Shenandoah Valley, and is again back on the upper waters of the Rappahannock, from which two months ago it set forth to capture Washington. The two corps of HILL and LONGSTREET reached Culpepper Court- house on Friday last, and the third corps, that of EWELL, has undoubtedly followed in their wake. One report is that they passed through Chester Gap of the Blue Ridge, six miles west of Manassas Gap. but our own dispatch says their march was through Thornton's Gap, twenty miles south of Chester Gap, and from thence to Sperryville, and so on down to Culpepper Court-house.

WASHINGTON, July 26. The Hon. John J. Crittenden died to-day. Rebel Morgan and the remainder of his band were captured to-day near New-Lisbon, Ohio. WASHINGTON, July 22, 1863. To D. Bookstaver, Mayor, Syracuse, New York: Volunteers will be received on your quota up to time of draft, and all who have been mustered into the United States service up to that time must be credited on your quota by your Board of Enrollment I cannot tell when the draft will take place in your city. JAMES B. FRY, Provost-Marshal-General.

WASHINGTON, July 25. The steamer Merrimac has been captured running the blockade at Wilmington, North Carolina. NEW-ORLEANS, La., Saturday, July 18, 1863. This city is suddenly galvanized into new life by the presence of a large body of officers who, for weeks past, plunged up to their necks in warlike duties before Port Hudson. The new military order issued by Gen. EMORY, compelling all officers to carry their side arms in the streets, gives the place a very martial appearance, and the clanking of spurs and sabers, which greets one at every turn, produces quite an impressive music.

WASHINGTON, July 24. Col. Toland has attacked the enemy at Wytheville, on the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad, capturing two pieces of artillery, 700 muskets and 125 prisoners. The following dispatches give the rebel version of affair in the vicinity of Jackson: JACKSON, Tuesday, July 7. Vicksburgh has fallen. It was surrendered on the morning of the 4th. the men being in a starving condition, completely worn out by excessive fatigue. By the terms of capitulation, the officers are allowed to retain their side-arms horses, and all their private property. They and the men are to be paroled immediately, and allowed to march out with all their colors.

WASHINGTON, July 23. To-day there was a sharp fight near Front Royal, Virginia. REWARD FOR DESERTERS. WAR DEPARTMENT ADJUTANT-GENERAL's OFFICE WASHINGTON July 16,1863. GENERAL ORDERS No. 222. -- The reward of SX 5, with transportation and reasonable expenses, for the arrest and delivery at the nearest military post or depot of any officer or private soldier fit for duty who may be found absent from his command without just cause, is hereby increased to SX 10.

WASHINGTON, July 22. A railroad bridge that was 350 feet long, over the Tar River at Rocky Mount, North Carolina, has been destroyed by a cavalry expedition from Newbern. They also destroyed a large amount of property. Brashear City, Louisiana, has been recaptured by our troops. A boy employed in carrying telegraphic messages was arrested, to-day, for opening them and conveying valuable information thus obtained to his brother, on LEE's Staff.

WASHINGTON, July 21. The only signs of the rebels in our immediate front is a party of forty of MOSEBY's guerrillas, who are pursuing their usual avocation of horse stealing in the vicinity of Occoquan Creek. Last night a band of guerillas came within two miles of Fort Ethan Allen, near the Chain Bridge, and stole twenty horses. Eleven hundred rebel prisoners, captured at Williamsport, arrived here last night, and were consigned to the Old Capitol Prison. The recent battles at Gettysburgh have furnished evidence of the necessity of some such organization of an QN Ambulance Corps, QN as was sought to be attained in the bill defeated by Congress at the last session.

WASHINGTON, July 20. Gov. Seymour of New York has ordered the return of the state arms used against the rioters in New York city. There has been a cavalry reconnaissance to Front Royal, Virginia. A sharp fight has occurred with the rebel guerrilla Morgan, and large portions of his force have been captured at George's Creek. An expedition of Union troops have destroyed railroad and other property at Rocky Mount, North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, July 19. The rebel Morgan made an unsuccessful attempt to cross the Ohio River. More of his men were captured. Two companies of rebels and an ammunition train have been captured at Jackson, Tennessee. Major-Gen. HURLBUT telegraphs from Memphis, July 17, to the War Department, as follows: QN The enemy's cavalry was sharply punished at Jackson, Tenn., by Col. HATCH, on the 13th. Then loss was two hundred in killed, wounded and prisoners, four hundred conscripts released, and about two hundred and fifty horses taken, with more than that number of arms. QN

WASHINGTON, July 18. Fort Wagner in Charleston harbor has been stormed. Gen. Foster has arrived at Fort Monroe. Gen. Lee's rear guard has departed Martinsburgh, Virginia. Morgan's force has dispersed and a large number of his men have been captured. There has been a fight with Morgan's men at Buffington, Ohio. Admiral Porter has reported the complete success of the Red River expedition. Fort Wagner in Charleston harbor has been bombed, the fort stormed, and our troops repulsed.

NEW YORK, July 17. The Seventh Regiment has arrived in New York. Quiet is restored in this city. the draft riot is suppressed. Gen. Brown is succeeded by Gen. Canby in command of the troops in New York. Archbishop Hughes has made a speech to the mob. WASHINGTON, July 17. A battle occurred to-day with the rebel Gen. Morgan at Berlin, Ohio. Two expeditions, one up the Red River and one to Natches--have made large captures of arms, ammunition, and cattle. NASHVILLE, Tenn., Friday, July 10. The guerrillas have again interrupted communication by rail between here and Louisville. Since Friday evening no train has reached us from the latter city.

WASHINGTON, July 16. Jefferson Davis has issued a proclamation immediately conscripting every able-bodied man between the ages of 18 and 45. Gen. Blunt has crossed the Arkansas River. Gen. Joe Johnston has evacuated Jackson, Mississippi, in the night. The rebels have been routed in Indian Country. There was a brisk engagement to-day on James Island, South Carolina. Gen. Blunt is victorious over 5,000 rebels at Elk Creek. Jackson, Mississippi, has been taken by our army. NEW YORK, July 16. The draft riot in New York is continuing. Archbishop Hughes has invited the mob to visit him at his residence on the morrow.

NEW YORK, July 15. The draft riot in this city is continuing. The military is routed, more negroes are hung, and there is terrible excitement in New York and the neighborhoods. Mayor Opdyke has made a proclamation. A mob in Troy has destroyed the Times office and other property. Gen. Dix has been ordered to New York and Gen. J. G. Foster to Fort Monroe. WASHINGTON, July 15. A proclamation of the President was issued to-day, appointing August 6 for a National Thanksgiving for our great victories. C. L. Vallandigham has appeared at Niagara Falls, Canada, from his journey through the Southern states. Jackson, Mississippi has been shelled by our forces.

NEW YORK, July 14. The draft riot is continuing to-day in this city. Business is suspended, negroes have been hung, Col. O'Brien has been killed, there is conflict between the mob and soldiers. Gov. Seymour has made a proclamation and a speech to his friends. Postmaster Wakeman's house is destroyed. WASHINGTON, July 14. A riot occurred to-day in Boston. Gen. Meade's army is advancing. Our cavalry is occupying Falling Waters, on the Potomac, and have captured a brigade of rebels. Williamsport, Maryland, is occupied by our forces. Admiral Lee has captured Fort Powhattan, on the James River.

NEW YORK, July 13. A great draft riot has commenced in this city. The drafting office in Third Avenue is destroyed, a negro hung, and public and private property is destroyed. WASHINGTON, July 13. Gen. Lee's army has escaped across the Potomac River in the night. Gen. Meade has reconnoitered the rebel position and is reportedly making preparations for an attack. There has been an engagement at Jackson. Yazoo City has been captured by our troops. FREDERICK, Md., Tuesday, July 7. The latest intelligence from the front places LEE'S headquarters at Hagerstown to-day. The prospect of another conflict ere crossing the river is not promising.

WASHINGTON, July 12. Our forces have entered Hagerstown, Maryland. The rebels evacuated the town during the night. Our forces have passed through South Mountain and have come up with the rebel army of Gen. R. E. Lee securely posted on the heights of March's Run. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, July 8. A dispatch from Gen. GRANT to Gen. HALLECK, dated at Vicksburgh, at half-past 10 o'clock on the morning of the 4th of July, states that the rebels surrendered this morning, and that their troops were paroled as prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, July 11. There has been a brilliant engagement on Morris Island in Charleston harbor. All of the batteries have been evacuated by the rebels who are defending themselves in Fort Wagner. A draft has commenced in New York City. PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, July 7 -- 2 P.M. The State House bell is ringing a joyful pea over the capture of Vicksburgh. All the fire-bells in the city are also now ringing, by direction of the Mayor, sent through the police telegraph. PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, July 7. The newspaper offices are illuminated this evening. The Ledger building has stars placed along the entire front. The North American has the word QN Victory. QN

WASHINGTON, July 10. Gen. Gillmore has commenced operations against the rebel batteries on Morris Island, Charleston harbor. Gen. Strong has taken possession of several of the rebel works. Martial law has been declared in Louisville, Kentucky. An engagement has begun at Jackson, Mississippi and at Sharpsburgh, Maryland. A skirmish has occurred near Funkstown, Maryland. WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 7. Officers arrived this evening from the flag of truce boat last sent to City Point, bring back rebel news, and files of Richmond papers to July 4. Profound ignorance was existing as to the whereabouts of LEE'S forces, and the progress of the great battle.

WASHINGTON, July 9. Port Hudson has been taken possession by the Union army. Our cavalry have scored a victory under Gens. Buford and Kilpatrick at Boonsboro. HARRISBURGH, Sunday, July 5. Surgeon-Gen. Hammond, Washington: Our people over the State are exceedingly anxious to render aid and assistance to the wounded at Gettysburgh. Will you say how many volunteer Surgeons I may send. You may be assured that our people will take the wounded to their houses, and render every assistance that the most careful nursing may demand, and that our public buildings can be used as hospitals to any extent.

WASHINGTON, July 8. To-day, Port Hudson surrendered with 7,000 prisoners and a large number of cannon and small arms, to Gen. Banks. The rebel Gen. Morgan has crossed into Indiana and captured the town of Corydon. Gen. Gillmore issued orders for an attack on Morris Island in Charleston harbor. GETTYSBURGH, July 4. GENERAL ORDERS NO. 68. -- The Commanding General, in behalf the country, thanks the Army of the Potomac for the glorious result of the recent operations. Our enemy, superior in numbers, and flushed with the pride of a successful invasion, attempted to overcome or destroy this army but has now withdrawn from the contest.

WASHINGTON, July 7. A battle commenced to-day at Williamsport, Maryland. The rebel Gen. Morgan's force currently appears to be at Bardstown, Kentucky. Rebel Gen. Bragg's army is now retreating across the Tennessee River. Gen. Meade is in pursuit of Gen. R. E. Lee. TULLAHOMA, Saturday, July 4. The telegraph wires have been extended to this place. TULLAHOMA, Monday, July 6 -- 3 A.M. Maj. Gen. THOMAS has succeeded in crossing the Elk River, with his corps and a division of cavalry, under Gen. STANLEY, and is in close pursuit of BRAGG's army, with every prospect of capturing their wagon train and rear guard.

WASHINGTON, July 6. Rebel Gen. Johnston has been defeated on the Big Black River. His rear guard has been captured at Bolton. The rebel army from Gettysburgh has arrived at Hagerstown, Maryland. Rebel Gen. Stuart has been defeated by Gen. Buford at Hanover. THURSDAY, July 2, 1863, 12 Meridian. The engagement yesterday was very sharp, and one of the bloodiest, for its duration, yet encountered by the Army of the Potomac. It was entirely between our Advance Guard, the First corps, supported subsequently by the Eleventh, and the combined forces of the rebel Generals HILL and EWELL.

WASHINGTON, July 5. At Gettysburgh, the day is occupied by Gen. Meade in succoring the wounded and burying the dead left on the field. PHILADELPHIA, July 4. A dispatch has been received here from Washington announcing that Vicksburgh had been captured. During the evening, however, it was ascertained that the story was false. The Government yesterday received dispatches from Gen. GRANT to the 27th, stating that the siege was progressing finely. Another attack was expected from JOHNSTON during this week, but in the meantime Vicksburgh was expected to surrender.

WASHINGTON, July 4. Vicksburgh, Mississippi, surrendered to-day to Gen. U. S. Grant. Surrendered are 31,000 troops, 220 guns, and 70,000 small arms. A Union victory also occurred to-day at Helena, Arkansas. The retreat of the rebels from the battlefield at Gettysburg has commenced. President Lincoln has issued a proclamation announcing a victory at Gettysburgh. Gen. Meade has issued a congratulatory address to his army on the victory of Gettysburgh. It is reported that Alexander Stevens, Vice President of the Confederate States, applied for permission to visit Washington as bearer of a letter from Jefferson Davis to President Lincoln. His application was refused.

WASHINGTON, July 3. The battle at Gettysburg is continuing to-day. There are heavy losses on both sides. A great victory appears to be gained by the Union army and the rebels are compelled to retreat. The rebel pontoon bridge over the Potomac near Williamsport, Maryland, has been destroyed. A cavalry expedition from Newbern, North Carolina, has departed for the interior. GETTYSBURGH, Thursday 4:30 P.M. Via BALTIMORE, Friday A.M. The day has been quiet up to the present moment. The enemy are now massing a heavy force on our left, and have just began the attack with artillery. The probability is that a severe battle will be fought before dark.

WASHINGTON, July 2. The battle at Gettysburgh is continuing to-day. The rebels have attacked our forces in large numbers, but have been repulsed. Gens. Weed and Zook were killed to-day and Gen. Sickles has been wounded. The rebel Gen. Barksdale, of Mississippi, is killed. Chambersburgh and Shippensburgh, Pennsylvania, have been evacuated by the rebels. A skirmish occurred to-day near Bottom's Bridge, Virginia. Tullahoma, Tennessee, is now occupied by our forces. BALTIMORE, Thursday, July 2. The American learns from parties who left Gettysburgh at noon to-day that everything was progressing favorably for the ultimate success of our arms.

WASHINGTON, July 1. A battle has commenced to-day at Gettysburgh, Pennsylvania. The First and Eleventh Corps have been significantly engaged. Gen. Reynolds has been killed. There are large losses on both sides. A brilliant fight occurred at Carlisle between the rebel cavalry and artillery of Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, and our forces under the command of Gen. W. F. Smith. PHILADELPHIA, Sunday, June 28. The report from Harrisburgh, at midnight of Saturday, that the rebels had arrived opposite Duncannon, at the junction of the Juniata and Susquehanna Rivers, is probably an error, as the telegraph line remains in order to Pittsburgh this (Sunday) morning.

WASHINGTON, June 30. York, Pennsylvania, was evacuated overnight by the rebels. Martial law was proclaimed to-day in Baltimore. A skirmish has occurred at Sporting Hill, Pennsylvania, near Oyster Point. A cavalry battle occurred to-day at Hanover Junction, Pennsylvania. A skirmish has occurred at Mechanicsburgh, Pennsylvania. Gen. Buford has reportedly passed through Gettysburgh on a reconnaissance in force. HARRISBURGH, Penn., Thursday, June 25, 1863. At no period during the present invasion of that of last year has there been so much excitement in Harrisburgh as now.

WASHINGTON, June 29. Wrightsville, Pennsylvania, has been evacuated by the rebels. To-day there was a fight at McConnelsburgh, Pennsylvania. Gen. Meade's army is moving in the vicinity of Emmettsburgh and New-Windsor. HARRISBURGH, Penn., Saturday, June 27, 1863. The rebels are slowly advancing toward this place, having entered Carlisle at 1 P.M. Telegraphic communication with Carlisle was suspended at about 12 M. Our forces have retired to Mechanicsburgh, which is nine miles from Harrisburgh. All the ammunition, knapsacks and surplus clothing of the advance force have been sent here by rail.

WASHINGTON, June 28. Gen. Hooker has been relieved of the command of the Army of the Potomac and Gen. Meade has been appointed in his place. The rebels are now within four miles of Harrisburgh, Pennsylvania. The bridge over the Susquehanna at Columbia, Pennsylvania, has been burned. Mechanicsburgh, Pennsylvania, has surrendered to the rebels. Brookville, Maryland, is now occupied by the rebels. At Donaldsonville, Louisiana, the rebels attempted to take the Federal fort to-day.

WASHINGTON, June 27. The advance of Gen. Rosecrans' army has arrived at Manchester, Tennessee. Kingston, Pennsylvania, is now occupied by the rebels. York, Pennsylvania, is also occupied. Chambersburgh, Pennsylvania, is occupied by the divisions of the rebel army under Gens. Longstreet and Hill. PITTSBURGH, June 25. Last night, about 10 o'clock, a message was received in the telegraph office here from McConnellsburgh, which left no doubt that the line at that point was in possession of the rebels. The rebel operator does not appear to have been gifted with any great degree of sharpness, as he made himself known the moment he attached his instrument.

WASHINGTON, June 26. Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, is now occupied by the rebels. Gov. Curtin issued another proclamation to the people of Pennsylvania. The rebel privateer Archer, with the crew of the Tacony has reportedly entered Portland Harbor and captured the revenue cutter Caleb Cushing. This enterprise has resulted in the capture of the Archer by the Union navy. White House, Virginia, is now occupied by our troops. BALTIMORE, Monday, June 22. A body of cavalry belonging to Gen. COUCH'S command entered Frederick yesterday afternoon, and drove the rebels out of the place. It is now believed there are no rebels in Frederick County.

WASHINGTON, June 25. Fairfax Court-House, Virginia, is now occupied by the rebels. A skirmish occurred to-day at Marysville, Pennsylvania, near Harrisburgh. Another engagement has occurred at Liberty Gap, Tennessee. An expedition reportedly left West Point, Virginia, for the interior. One rebel fort at Vicksburg was destroyed to-day by the explosion of one of our mines. The cargo ship Constitution has been captured by the privateer Georgia. The Union army has crossed the Potomac at Edwards' Ferry. Gen. Rosecrans has reportedly resumed his march.

WASHINGTON, June 24. Shippensburg, Pennsylvania, has been reached by a portion of the rebel army. Sever skirmish of Gen. Rosecrans' army has occurred at Hoover's Gap, Tennessee, and has been successful to our arms as a result. The rebels have been driven from Liberty Gap, near Murfreesboro. Heavy skirmishing has commenced near Murfreesboro. The main body of Lee's army has reportedly entered Maryland, crossing the Potomac at Shepperdstown and Williamsport. HARRISBURGH, Penn., Tuesday, June 23, 1863. At 11 O'clock last night dispatches were received by Gen. COUCH, informing him that rebel scouts had reentered Greencastle.

WASHINGTON, June 23. Chambersburgh, Pennsylvania, is now reoccupied by the rebels. ALBANY, Tuesday, June 16. The Governor is receiving urgent messages from the authorities of Pennsylvania asking for troops, and is doing everything possible to hurry them forward. Gov. CURTIN advises that they be shipped via Easton. Secretary STANTON telegraphs that the men will not be needed for more than 30 days, and probably not for that period. that arms will be supplied to them at Harrisburgh, and that they report to Gen. COUGH.

WASHINGTON, June 22. Rebels now occupy Millerstown, Pennsylvania. The portion of rebel Gen. Ewell's corps which had not yet arrived in Pennsylvania has now crossed the Potomac and moved up the valley. Rebels are driven from Cumberland, Maryland. HARRISBURGH, Saturday, June 20. A heavy force of rebels continue to linger in the vicinity of Hagerstown and Williamsport. Scouts sent out from Chambersburgh, report that their movements this morning indicate a retreat to the other side of the Potomac, but this afternoon they moved up in the direction of McConnellsville and Bedford. Gen. MILROY is on the alert for them.

WASHINGTON, June 21. A great cavalry engagement is underway near Middleburgh and Upperville, Virginia. The rebels are driven from Frederick, Maryland. HARRISBURGH, Sunday, June 14. Dispatches received from the operators at Chambersburgh and Hagerstown give the information of negroes who have arrived there, to the effect that the rebel cavalry arrived at Perrysville and Martinsburgh about noon, and at the latter place there had been considerable hard fighting. Gen. MILROY was contesting the advance of the rebels. Telegraph communication is destroyed between Winchester and Martinsburgh, the lines having been broken by the rebels about 11 A.M.

WASHINGTON, June 20. The ship Isaac Webb has been captured and bonded by the Tacony. Rebels have been driven out of Frederick, Maryland. PHILADELPHIA, Monday, June 15. The movements of the rebels on the borders of the State caused much excitement at the Corn Exchange this morning, and trade was partially suspended. PHILADELPHIA, Monday, June 15. The principal citizens of this city have telegraphed to Gen. GEORGE CADWALLADER, now at Washington, asking him to obtain authority to repair immediately to Philadelphia, and organize the troops, his petitioners regarding him as a man fit for the crisis.

SHIPPENSBURGH, PENN. Friday, June 19, 9 A.M. Last night considerable excitement was created in this place by the arrival of farmers from the neighborhood of Chambersburgh, who brought with them all their stock or horses, in anticipation of the advance of the rebels. The town is one vast stable. The rebels hold Greencastle with a force of two hundred men. They are scouting the country in all directions in search of horses. Last night a traitor led the rebels to a gap in the mountain near Greencastle, where they took sixty horses which had been secreted by citizens. The apparent object of the rebels is to obtain horses and run off negroes.

WASHINGTON, June 18. From MEMPHIS, Friday, June 12. The steamer Fort Wayne, from Young's Point, arrived here to-day. She brings no later dates from Vicksburgh than the 8th inst. No guerrillas were seen on the way up. The fight at Milliken's Bend on, Sunday last, was much larger than at first reported. The rebels under MCCULLOUGH, 2,500 strong, advanced upon the Federal forces, composed of three negro regiments and the Twenty-third Iowa Volunteers. The rebels made a desperate charge at daylight. The negroes broke in confusion, but finding that their captured companions were being slaughtered by the rebels. rallied with great desperation.

HARRISBURGH, Wednesday, June 17. No doubt whatever exists as to the presence of the enemy at Chambersburgh up to about 3 o'clock this afternoon, when they retreated, it is supposed, toward Hagerstown. The operator is at Chambersburgh, and telegraphic communication has been reestablished. BALTIMORE, Wednesday, June 17. Hagerstown dispatches are very unreliable. Trains arrived this evening from Westminster, bringing also passengers from Emmittsburgh, who report no rebels in that section of the country. The excitement along the line toward Harrisburgh was abating.

WASHINGTON, June 16. Harper's Ferry has been reached by Gen. Milroy's army. Gov. Parker of New Jersey has to-day called for volunteers to repel the invasion of Philadelphia. Harper's Ferry has been invested and attacked. Our forces have retired to Maryland Heights and have shelled the rebels out. HARRISBURGH, Tuesday, June 16, 1863. The telegraph offices at Carsisle and Shippensburgh are still open, and business is transacted with them as usual. As Shippensburgh is twenty miles beyond Carlisle, it is evident that the rebels are not advancing with much rapidity, and there is to-night a fair prospect of securing the Capital against attack, if the rebels advance.

HARRISBURGH, June 15. The telegraph operator left Chambersburgh at 9 o'clock to-night, some time after the rebels had entered the town. His instrument is now in operation five miles east of Chambersburgh, at Scotland Bridge. A.G. CURTIN. The operator from Chambersburgh says that a great fire is now raging at Greencastle. The column that entered Greencastle consisted of 5,000 cavalry, supported by infantry and artillery. The fire at Greencastle is believed to indicate a determination on the part of the rebels to burn, plunder and destroy our cities. Gov. CURTIN and Gen. COUCH are working night and day. The bells are rung and people are assembling en masse.

WASHINGTON, June 14. A skirmish occurred to-day at State Creek, Kentucky. Berryville and Martinsburgh have been occupied by the rebels. The Army of the Potomac has reportedly left Falmouth for Pennsylvania in pursuit of Gen. Lee's forces. Port Hudson has been assaulted. Our forces were repulsed with heavy losses. HEADQUARTERS, NINETEENTH ARMY CORPS. IN THE FIELD NEAR PORT HUDSON, June 1, 1863. No person, military officer or other, will take from any plantation worked by the U.S. Quartermaster's Department, any article of property whatever, or in any way interfere with the working of the same.

WASHINGTON, June 13. The town of Eunice, near Vicksburgh, has been destroyed by our gunboats. Winchester, Virginia, has been attacked and its armament and part of its garrison has been captured. MURFREESBORO, Tennessee, Tuesday, June 9. Col. LAWRENCE WILLIAMS ORTON, formerly LAWRENCE WILLIAMS, of the Second United States cavalry, one time on Gen. SCOTT'S Staff, and late Gen. BEAGG'S Chief of Artillery, and Lieut. DUNLAP, of the rebel army, were arrested and hung as spies last night, at Franklin.

WASHINGTON, June 12. Governor Curtin of Pennsylvania has issued a proclamation calling for volunteers to repel the anticipated invasion of that State by rebels. Gen. Couch assumed command of the Department of the Susquehanna. President Lincoln has reportedly addressed a letter to Erastus Corning and others, in relation to the arrest of Vallandigham etc. Gen. Hunter has left the Department of the South. Gen. Q. A. Gillmore has assumed command. A brisk engagement between Union batteries on Folly Island and rebel batteries on Morris Island has occurred in Charleston Harbor.

WASHINGTON, June 11. C. L. Vallandigham was nominated for Governor of Ohio to-day. Darien, Georgia, has reportedly been destroyed by our forces. The Herald has been destroyed by Union gunboats in Charleston Harbor. The steamer Calypso has been captured. Gen. Halleck has directed the garrisons at Martinsburgh and Winchester, Virginia, to retire to Harper's Ferry. Tribune, Tennessee, has been attacked by rebels.

WASHINGTON, June 10. The draft in Indiana has been resisted. An engagement occurred to-day near Monticello, Kentucky. Lake Providence was attacked by rebels and successfully defended by negro troops. The Havelock sunk off Charleston bar. CINCINNATI, Monday, June 8. Two thousand rebel prisoners left Indianapolis on Saturday for Fort Delaware. One hundred and sixty-five officers of PEMBERTON's were sent to Johnston's Island. CINCINNATI, Monday, June 8. Maj.-Gen. AMBROSE E. BURNSIDE returned to this city on Saturday, the 6th inst.

WASHINGTON, June 9. a severe cavalry engagement at brandy Station or Beverly's Ford, Virginia, occurred to-day on the Rappahannock. Rebels have been driven from Monticello, Kentucky. The Departments of Monongahela and Susquehanna were created to-day. Gen. Rosecrans executed two spies to-day. HEADQUARTERS ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Saturday, June 6, 1863. The boldest reconnaissance of the war was begun yesterday afternoon by a portion of this army. For the third time in six months, the Rappahannock has been successfully crossed by our brave men, with slight loss.

NEW YORK, June 8. The telegraph has not taken the trouble either to contradict or confirm the story it brought us, a few days since, that the rebels had captured a regiment of negro soldiers at Helena, Arkansas, and had hung every man of them, with all their white officers. We should think that when it was thought worth while to startle the whole country with a rumor of this kind, it would also be considered worth while to contradict it when it was proven to be false. The absurd stories which are often telegraphed to the Press may, perhaps, not be thought worthy of contradiction, but the fact is they deceive many people, and leave many others in doubt.

WASHINGTON, June 7. The Battle of Milliken's Bend has concluded to-day. THE VICKSBURGH WOUNDED. Assistant Surgeon-Gen. WOOD telegraphs to the Department here that the wounded from Vicksburgh are being removed as rapidly as possible to hospitals at Memphis and elsewhere. Large quantities of ice and other comforts have been forwarded from St. Louis for the use of the wounded. The Medical Department is now prepared to furnish, free of charge, artificial arms to such soldiers as have lost their natural ones in battle.

WASHINGTON, June 6. The bark Whistling Wind was destroyed by a privateer to-day. Rebels have attacked Milliken's Bend and Young's Point, near Vicksburgh, but were repulsed. Shawneetown, Kansas, has reportedly been destroyed by guerrillas. WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 4. A party of contrabands direct from Culpepper, who arrived at Union Mills yesterday, report that a few days since three rebel brigades of infantry arrived at Culpepper from the Rappahannock, and the soldiers said they were going to Richmond. The bridge over the Rapidan has been rebuilt, so that trains pass over the road from Culpepper to Richmond.

WASHINGTON, June 5. From MURFREESBORO, Tennessee, Wednesday, June 3. Scouts who have thoroughly scoured the country on our left and in our rear, report having neither seen nor heard of any rebels. A gentleman who is known here, and whose statements are regarded as reliable, has just reached our lines from Tullahoma. This gentleman says there are not more than two regiments at that place, and that the enemy have thrown all their forces forward to Shelbyville Beech Grove and other points on our immediate front.

WASHINGTON, June 4. Our forces at Franklin, Tennessee, have been attacked. Gen. Burnside has revoked his order suppressing the New-York World and Chicago Times, by order of the President. An expedition has departed King William County, Virginia, from Yorktown, with good results. To-day there was a brisk fight at Sataria, on the Yazoo River. NEW YORK, June 4. The total subscriptions in America to the Atlantic Telegraph stock to date are PX 66.615. Every person in the United States, and the British North American Provinces owning any of the stock of the Atlantic Telegraph Company has shown his confidence in the enterprise by subscribing for new stock.

WASHINGTON, June 3. To-day there is a great peace meeting in New York. Gen. Lee has reportedly broken up camp at Fredericksburgh, Virginia. CHICAGO, Tuesday, June 2. The proprietors of the Times were notified to-night by Capt. PUTNAM, commanding Camp Douglas, that if they attempted to issue their paper for to-morrow morning, he would, in accordance with a telegraphic order from Gen. AMMEN, take military possession of the office. Judge DRUMMOND, of the United States Court, was Immediately applied to for a writ enjoining Capt. PUTNAM from any interference whatever with the Times office.

WASHINGTON, June 2. Gen. Burnside has suppressed the circulation of the New-York World and Chicago Times in his department. CINCINNATI Saturday, May 30. There are no later advices from Murfreesboro. It is believed that the Army of the Cumberland is in motion. Gen. BURNSIDE will soon take the field. Gen. HARTSUFF has issued Order No. 1, assuming command of the troops in Kentucky, except the Ninth army corps and Gen. CARTER's division, with headquarters at Lexington. Brig.-Gen. BAYLE has charge of the railroad and depot guards throughout the State.

WASHINGTON, June 1. To-day there was a meeting of Vallandigham sympathizers at Philadelphia. James Island has been evacuated by the Union troops. Col. Grierson's men, in their famous raid through Louisiana, had a very clever way of cutting the telegraph wires so as to avoid discovery. Instead of cutting the wires and letting the ends hang loosely, they tied up the ends with strips of leather, so that it could not be easily seen and yet the connection was severed.

WASHINGTON, May 31. Skirmishing reportedly occurred to-day near Monticello, Kentucky. The schooner Echo has been captured. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has just made the following highly important decision, covering the whole ground of the income tax: The income tax must be assessed and paid in the district in which the assessed person resides. The place where a person votes, or is entitled to vote, is deemed his residence. When not a voter, the place where the tax on personal property is paid is held to be the place of residence.

WASHINGTON, May 30. An attack on a train of cars near Catlett's Station, Virginia, by Moseby's rebel cavlry occurred to-day. Moseby's force has been defeated near Greenwich, Virginia. A train of cars was destroyed near Kettle Run, Virginia. CINCINNATI, Friday, May 29. It is reported that Gen. BRAGG telegraphed to JEFF. DAVIS as to what he should do with Mr. VALLANDIGHAM. JEFF. DAVIS replied, if Mr. VALLANDIGHAM would take the oath of allegiance to the Southern Confederacy, to receive him, and if not to send him back.

WASHINGTON, May 29. A skirmish occurred to-day at Thoroughfare Gap, Virginia. Gen. Kilpartirck left Yorktown on a raid up the Peninsula with good success so far. PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 27. MARION DAY, for many years an operator of the American Telegraph Company, died this morning, after a severe and painful illness. MOBILE, Monday, May 25. A special dispatch to the Evening News, dated Jackson, May 24, (Sunday,) says firing was heard till 9 o'clock this morning. No report of artillery has been heard since that hour. This morning the Twentieth Mississippi regiment (mounted) dashed into Raymond, capturing 400 prisoners.

WASHINGTON, May 28. An attack on Port Hudson is continuing to-day. Our forces have been repulsed. From a special reporter in Jackson Mississippi, May 17. The Catholic church of this place was destroyed, and the Mississippian Office gutted, the presses broken, and the type thrown into the street. The furniture in the Capitol was badly abused, and the Governor's mansion demolished. Ladies were robbed of jewelry and money. All the stores were sacked, and their contents destroyed, iron safes broken open. The railroad was badly torn up for several miles, and the telegraph wires torn down. About three hundred negroes from Hinds County joined the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, May 27. Kearney medals were presented to-day to the Third Army Corps. Rebels have been defeated at Florence, Alabama. An attack on Port Hudson has commenced. The Union gunboat Cincinnati was sunk by rebel batteries at Vicksburgh. WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 26. Arrangements are nearly finished to make a draft as soon as the enrollment under the Conscription law has been completed. An order from the War Department furnishes the long-promised rules and regulations for negro enlistments.

NEW YORK, May 26. Messrs. GLASS, ELLIOT ES CO., of London, the large and wealthy manufacturers of submarine telegraph cables, offer to manufacture and lay down a good and durable sub-marine cable between Ireland and Newfoundland, on condition that they are paid each week their actual disbursements for labor and materials, and that when the cable is laid and in good working order, they shall receive interest on capital and profit, twenty per cent, provided the cable at the end of each successive month shall be found in perfect working order. This great international work will now be pushed forward without delay, and completed during the summer of 1864.

WASHINGTON, May 25. Gen. GRANT'S army is in Vicksburgh, and that his victory is complete. We had previously learned that the outer works had been taken -- that Haines' Bluff batteries, immediately on the north, the Warrenton batteries immediately on the south, and the line of the Big Black River, including the great railroad bridge, in the rear, were all in our hands. Gen. GRANT fought five pitched battles with the rebels, in all of which he had been successful. We had seen how skillfully he divided their forces. We knew that he had committed terrible havoc in the enemy's ranks, had captured in the vicinity of 10,000 prisoners and an immense quantity of artillery.

WASHINGTON, May 24. An official dispatch from Memphis, which the President has furnished to the Press, announcing a great battle in the vicinity of Vicksburgh, and the capture by Gen. GRANT of the outer works of the place, with a large number of prisoners and fifty-seven pieces of artillery. The battle, it is said, was still raging on Wednesday. We are not told when it opened, nor its precise locality. but if we really hold the points mentioned in the dispatch, it must have been close in the rear of the great stronghold. Haines' Bluff, as our readers know, is directly north of Vicksburgh, and has always been considered the key of the position.

WASHINGTON, May 23. The battle at Gum Swamp, North Carolina, is continuing to-day. Gen. Bank's forces met in junction with Gen. Augur's forces at Bayou Sara, Louisiana, to-day. A DISPATCH FROM GEN. JOE JOHNSTON. CAMP BETWEEN LIVINGSTON AND BROWNSVILLE, Miss., May 18, 1863. To Gen. S. Cooper: Lieut.-Gen. PEMBERTON was attacked by the enemy on the morning of the 16th inst., near Edwards' depot, and after nine hours' fighting was compelled to fall back behind the Big Black. J.D. JOHNSTON, General Com'd'g.

WASHINGTON, May 22. The sentence for Vallandigham has been changed to banishment. The blockade runner Eagle has been captured. An assault on rebel works at Vicksburgh, Mississippi, is in progress. Yesterday, our forces were repulsed with severe losses. A battle began to-day at Gum Swamp, North Carolina. There has been an engagement at Port Hudson Plains.

WASHINGTON, May 21. There is no later news from Gen. GRANT this morning. This need cause no apprehension. he had notified the War Department that a cessation of intelligence from him for a short period, might be expected. A report was current in Cincinnati yesterday -- how it reached there is not explained -- that Gen. GRANT, after destroying the State House and rebel stores in Jackson, evacuated the place. This is quite likely to have been the case, if the report of the evacuation of Vicksburgh, and the movement of the rebels to the northward is true. The Government, our Washington correspondent says, expects to hear from Gen. GRANT to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 20. U.S. gunboat Isaac Smith, earlier captured by rebels and renamed steamer Stono, has been destroyed off Charleston, South Carolina. The bark Goodspeed has been destroyed by the Tacony. Vicksburg is being invested by Gen. Grant's forces. NEW YORK, May 20. CYRUS W. FIELD, Esq., has placed specimens of every kind of submarine cable now in use in the world on exhibition at the Merchants' Exchange Reading Room, Nos. 50 and 52 Pine-street. They embrace all the English, European and American cables, and are indeed a curiosity well worthy the inspection of the public, who are invited to view them.

WASHINGTON, May 19. Gen. Meagher took leave of his troops to-day. Richmond, Missouri, was sacked by guerrillas. Vicksburgh's fortifications have been assaulted. The blockade runner steamer Union has been captured. CINCINNATI, Tuesday, May 19. The defeat of the rebels at Raymond, Miss., is said to have been very disastrous to them. We are yet without particulars. Gen. GRANT took Jackson on the 14th inst., and burned the State Capitol. Heavy reinforcements were hurrying forward to the rebels, and stopping twelve miles east of Jackson. A great battle is imminent.

WASHINGTON, May 18. A meeting to express sympathy with Vallandigham was held to-day in New York. Vallandigham has been sentenced to confinement in Fort Warren. A Union victory has occurred on the Black River, Mississippi. Admiral Porter has captured Haines' Bluff, near Vicksburgh. The schooner Isabel has been destroyed, and the schooner Ripple has been captured, both off Mobile Bay.

WASHINGTON, May 17. The steamer Cuba has been pursued and destroyed and the schooner Hunter has been captured. A battle occurred to-day at Big Black River Bridge, Mississippi. From the Richmond Inquirer, May 13. HOW JACKSON WAS WOUNDED, HIS SUFFERINGS AND DEATH. Gen. JACKSON, having gone some distance in front of the line of skirmishers on Saturday evening, was returning about 8 o'clock, attended by his Staff and part of his couriers. The cavalcade was in the darkness of the night mistaken for a body of the enemy's cavalry, and fired upon by a regiment of his own corps. He was struck by three balls and bled to death.

WASHINGTON, May 16. The cavalry captured by the rebels at Charlestown, Maryland, have been freed by Union forces. Rebels under Gen. Pemberton have been defeated at Edward's Station, Mississippi. A great battle occurred to-day at Baker's Creek, near Vicksburgh, and is now being called the Battle of Champion's Hill. There was an engagement at Berry's Ferry, Virginia.

WASHINGTON, May 15. A company of U.S. cavalry has been captured at Charlestown, Maryland. Rebel stores were destroyed at York River, Virginia. A fight occurred to-day at Carrsville, Virginia. The evacuation of Jackson, Mississippi, by Union troops has commenced. The British brigantine Cornet has been captured. The ship Byzantium was burned by the Tacony.

WASHINGTON, May 14. Jackson, Mississippi, has fallen to Gen. Grant. The resignation of Gen. Thos. F. Meagher was accepted to-day by the President. Clinton, Mississippi, is now occupied by Union troops. Senators WADE and CHANDLER, after a lengthy interview to-day with the President and Secretary of War, left, this evening, in a special boat for the army. The President, to-night, received from the headquarters of the army of the Potomac an original letter of JEFFERSON DAVIS, addressed to one of his Colonels, in which he speaks despondingly of affairs in the Southwest and on the Rappahannock. The letter was found in a rebel camp.

WASHINGTON, May 13. Rebel forces have been defeated at Mississippi Spring, Mississippi. Gen. Joe Johnston has arrived at Jackson, Mississippi. Ar large amount of rebel property was destroyed to-day at Yazoo City. The schooner A. J. Hodge has been captured. The ship Crown Point has been burned by the Florida. BOSTON, May 13. -- Arrived ship Courier, Havre. brig Nahant, Remedios.

WASHINGTON, May 12. A Union victory has occurred to-day at Raymond, Mississippi. SAN FRANCISCO. May 11. -- Arrived steamer Orizaba, Panama: ship Panther, Lathrop, New-York. BOSTON. May 12. -- Arrived ship Hignland Chief, Newport: barks E.F. Herriman, Buenos Ayres. Smyrnite, Smyrna. brig Coquette, Cienfuegos. schr. Emma, do. At Barbados April 22, schooner Island Belle, Johnson, from Philadelphia, just arrived -- she had lost deck load, split sails, etc.

WASHINGTON, May 11. The news on Monday from the Philadelphia papers concerning the advance upon Richmond as having been sent by telegraph from Philadelphia to this City, and as having thus passed under the notice of the Government Censor. We have since learned that this was not so. It came from Philadelphia here by special messenger, and was only committed to the telegraph from this City to Boston, over the Independent line.

WASHINGTON, May 10. To-day, rebel Gen. Stonewall Jackson has reportedly died. PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, May 9. The Bulletin, of this City, publishes the following intelligence this evening: QN We learn from the editors of the Philadelphia Inquirer that one of their correspondents, who has just returned from Washington, informed them that Gen. Hooker recrossed the Rappahannock in force yesterday, the men carrying eight days' rations with them. We also learn from another source, that is vouched for as reliable, that Gen. Keyes has taken Richmond, having advanced upon it by way of Yorktown. and that the Federal flag now floats over the rebel Capital.

WASHINGTON, May 9. Rebel guerrillas have attacked at Horseshoe Bend, on the Cumberland River, Tennessee. The schooner Sea Lion has been captured off Mobile Bay. WASHINGTON, May 8, 1863. To the Governor of Pennsylvania: The President and the General-in-Chief have just returned from the Army of the Potomac. The principal operations of Gen. HOOKER failed, but there has been no serious disaster to the organization and efficiency of the army. It is now occupying its former position on the Rappahannock, having recrossed the river without any loss in the movement. Not more than one-third of Gen. HOOKER's force was engaged.

WASHINGTON, May 8. President Lincoln made a proclamation to-day in relation to the draft, defining the duties of persons of foreign birth. Gen. T. F. Meagher resigned his commission to-day. Gen. Banks has reached Alexandria, Louisiana, having captured on his expedition 2,000 prisoners, 20 artillery pieces, 2 transports, and a large amount of property. FORT MONROE, Wednesday, May 6. Col. LUDLOW, Commissioner for exchange of prisioners, has just returned from City Point, and has effected the release and exchange of all United States officers held by the rebels. These officers, 250 in number, and 325 men, include Gens. STOUGHTON and WILLICH.

WASHINGTON, May 7. President Lincoln and Gen. Halleck visited the Army of the Potomac at Falmouth, Virginia, this morning. Col Kilpatrick and a force of cavalry have arrived at Gloucester Point, Virginia. Gen. Whipple died to-day. The trial of C. L. Vallandigham concluded to-day. West Point, Virginia, is now occupied by Union forces. The bridges etc. near White House, Virginia, have been destroyed by Union forces. Gen. Lee issued a congratulatory address to his army. The steamer Cherokee has been captured off Charleston, South Carolina.

WASHINGTON, May 6. The trial of C. L. Vallandigham has commenced in Cincinatti. The Army of the Potomac continues to return across the Rappahannock. Gen. Hooker has issued an address to his army in respect to the battles at Chancellorsville. A severe battle has occurred at Clinton, Mississippi. The Steamer Eugenie has been captured off Mobilie Bay, by a Union gunboat. A battle at Fourteen-Mile Creek, near Vicksburgh, has commenced.

WASHINGTON, May 5. Meadow Bridge, on the Chickahominy, has been destroyed by Col. Kilpatrick's forces. The schooner Jupiter, a blockade runner, has been captured. The Honorable C. L. Vallandigham has been arrested at Dayton, Ohio, for treason. A riot broke out in an attempt to rescue him at Dayton. The Army of the Potomac has commenced to return from Chancellorsville, across the Rappahannock. Col. Kilpatrick has surprised some rebel cavalry at Aylett's Virginia. The governor of Mississippi has called on the people of the state to arouse for its defence.

WASHINGTON, May 4. Grand Gulf, Mississippi, has been captured by Admiral Porter's fleet. A battle occurred to-day at Salem Heights, near Fredericksburgh, Virginia. Gen. Stoneman's cavalry have now reportedly reached Beaver Dam, Ashland, and Hanover Court-house, Virginia. Newspaper correspondents have been captured when running past rebel batteries at Vicksburgh. Col. Kilpatrick's cavalry left Louisa Court-House, Virginia. Col. Streight's Union cavalry have been captured near Rome, Georgia. Gen. Stoneman's cavalry are now within two miles of Richmond, Virginia. He has reached the Chickahominy Bridge. Hungary, Virginia, has been reached by Col. Kilpatrick.

WASHINGTON, May 3. To-day there is terrific fighting at Chancellorsville. The Chancellor mansion has reportedly been shelled and burned by the rebels. Gen. Berry has been killed. Rebel Gen. Jackson has likely been mortally wounded. Gen. Sedgwick has attacked Fredericksburg. Mary's Hill has been stormed. There is great panic in Richmond due to the approach of Gen. Stoneman's cavalry. Columbia, Virginia, on the James River, has been reached by our cavalry who destroyed the canal there. Goochland, Virginia, has been visited by our cavalry. A fight has occurred at Suffolk, Virginia. Fighting continues near Warrenton, Virginia.

WASHINGTON, May 2. To-day the battle at Chancellorsville is continuing. Culpepper Court-house, Virginia, has fallen into Union hands. Big Black River, Mississippi, has been reached by Federal forces. Col. Grierson's cavalry force has reportedly reached Baton Rouge, Louisiana, from Tennessee. BALTIMORE, Saturday, May 2. The crisis with the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is past. The Confederates have all left it, moving southward, and our military forces are following and endeavoring to intercept them. The extent of the injury done to the road is now known. The line is intact, from the Monongahela River, three hundred miles distant, to Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, May 1. A battle has commenced at Chancellorsville, Virginia. Thompson's Hills, Mississippi, also known as Port Gibson, is occupied by Union forces. PORT ROYAL, Saturday, March 28. The Keokuk arrived yesterday. Four Monitors are in North Ecisto Inlet, with three mortar schooners, distant about 16 miles by land from Charleston. The troops landed at Stono are said to have accompanied a gunboat expedition. Firing has been heard there, but there is nothing definite from that quarter. The rebel pickets are visible all along the shores at North Edisto, and at night signals by colored lights are telegraphed along the coast from thence to Charleston.

WASHINGTON, April 30. To-day is Fast Day in the United States. Chancellorsville, Virginia, is now occupied by Gen. Hooker's army. Rebel Gen. Longstreet's army has commenced to withdraw from the south side of the James River. Gen. Grant's army has landed at Bruinsburg, Mississippi. FALMOUTH, APRIL 26. A few days ago a telegraph wire was discovered on the river bank. the finder touched it and received a slight shock. the fact was reported, and upon examination the important discovery was made that one end end of the line was within the enemy's lines, and the other in a house at Falmouth. The operator -- a rebel -- was arrested and is now in custody.

WASHINGTON, April 29. Gen. Hooker's forces to-day crossed the Rappahannock at Kelly's Ford in the advance upon Fredericksburgh. There has been an attack on the rebel batteries at Grand Gulf, Mississippi. Haines' Bluff near Vicksburgh has been bombarded. Orange Springs has been reached by Gen. Stoneman's cavalry. The ship Oneida has been destoryed by the Florida. The bark Henrietta has also been destroyed.

WASHINGTON, April 28. The U.S. sloop-of-war Preble has been destroyed by fire. A skirmish near Kinston, North Carolina, is continuing. Gen. Stoneman's cavalry have reportedly crossed the Rappahannock at Kelley's Ford. ST. LOUIS, Friday, April 24. The correspondent of the Democrat, of this city, writing from Rolla, says: QN Gen. MARMADUKE has a force of twenty thousand rebels in Southeast Missouri, and Gen. PRICE has a force of twelve thousand conscripts at Pocahontas. QN This is, doubtless, an exaggeration.

WASHINGTON, April 27. Gen. Stoneman's cavalry expedition has reportedly left Warrenton Junction, Virginia. WASHINGTON, April 24, 1863. One of the guards in the town of Falmouth, stationed outside a dwelling adjoining the brick church on the river bank, heard a choking like that of a telegraph instrument. He advised his superior officers, and was defected to enter the house and investigate. This was done, and on opening a door he discovcovered a party of four or five persons, one of whom was seated by a telegraph instrument, sending messages by a submarine wire across the Rappahannock. They were all arrested, and as their offense is of extraordinary atrocity.

WASHINGTON, April 26. Rebels at Cape Girardeau, Missouri, have been routed. The schooner Clarina, a blockade runner, has been captured. STONEMAN's STATION, Va., Saturday, April 25. Thursday morning's expedition, consisting of two regiments -- the Fourteenth Brooklyn and Nineteenth Indiana, under command of Col. MORROW, of the Twenty-fourth Michigan -- reached Port Conway, and at daylight launched several pontoons, crossed the river, and seized the town of Port Royal, which was occupied by a body of the enemy's cavalry, numbering not over two hundred. The cavalry were speedily dispersed, and twenty or more of them captured.

WASHINGTON, April 25. Tuscumbia, Alabama, is now reportedly occupied by our cavalry. The ship Dictator has been destroyed by the Georgia. MURFREESBORO, Tenn., Thursday, April 23. Refugees relieved from oppression at McMinnville, by a highly successful expedition by Gen. REYNOLDS, have arrived at Readyville. Gen. HAZEN telegraphs that they state that REYNOLDS took the town, capturing two railroad trains and a train of wagons. Among a number of prisoners taken was Mrs. JOHN MORGAN.

WASHINGTON, April 24. FORTRESS MONROE, Thursday, April 23. The flag-of-truce boat State of Maine, Capt. J. E. MULFORD, of the Third New-York regiment, has arrived from City Point. The Richmond papers of to-day contain telegraphic information from Port Hudson, confirming the loss of the steamers Queen of the West and Diana. The former got aground in Grand Lake, and was blown up by a shell from the Federal gunboat Calhoun. The Diana was burned by the rebels.

WASHINGTON, April 23. A Union raid has reportedly occurred on Middleton, Tennessee. Gen. Hunter addressed a letter to Jefferson Davis, threatening retaliation for the execution of negro soldiers and their officers. BOSTON, April 23. -- Arr. ship Lisbon, from New-York. bark John Bunyan, from Messina. Armenia, Constantinople. brigs Sea Lark, New-Orleans. Sparkling Sea, Buenos Ayres. Jesse, Matanzas.

WASHINGTON, April 22. McMinnville, Tennessee, has been taken by our troops and the rebel stores there have been destroyed. Tompkinsville, Kentucky, has been destroyed by our troops. A large force with gunboats has ran past the rebel batteries at Vicksburgh. A dispatch from Berwick Bay, dated the 15th inst., reports that there is a Federal force beyond Franklin, La., and marching on. There are no reports from Charleston later than the 17th, and they contain nothing new. Much interest is felt in Richmond in regard to matters at Suffolk. The papers admit that a battery has been captured. The tone of the editorials is desponding.

WASHINGTON, April 21. Gen. Halleck visited Suffolk, Virginia, to-day. NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, April 21. Steamship Hammonia, Hamburg 5th inst., via Southampton 8th, with mdse, and 172 passengers to Kunhardt Co. Had moderate winds but heavy sea during the passage. 8th inst., passed steamship Teutonia, going in the River Elbe. Gen. WRIGHT, in command at Louisville, telegraphs to Gen. BURNSIDE that the town of Celina was destroyed, together with 100,000 pounds of bacon, 10,000 bushels of wheat, 10,000 bushels of corn, 100 barrels of whisky, a quantity of flour, sugar, coffee, tea, etc., and forty boats, which had been used for transportation on the Cumberland.

WASHINGTON, April 20. A great mass meeting occurred to-day in New-York in commemoration of the grand uprising of the people in 1861. Gen. Banks' forces now occupy Opelousas and Washington, Louisiana. A rebel fort at Butte a la Rose, Louisiana, has been captured. Telegraphic communication with Norfolk was cut off for a short time day before yesterday, by a rebel guerrilla, who escaped with a patrol as a prize. The roads toward Norfolk and Portsmouth are now securely guarded. It is presumed that the rebels will attempt to destroy the railway tracks at Deep Creek, but the attempt, if made, will be foiled.
